subject: Learning
title: Cramming: Short-Term Win, Long-Term Loss
description: Learn Cramming: Short-Term Win, Long-Term Loss in one minute.

hook.text: The night before the exam, you study for eight hours straight. You pass. Two weeks later, it's gone.

buildup.text: Massed practice (cramming) frontloads effort into one intense session.

discovery.text: It works for short-term performance but creates fragile memories that decay rapidly.

twist.text: Spacing the same study hours across days produces far stronger, longer-lasting memory.

climax.text: Cramming is optimized for tomorrow's test. Spacing is optimized for lasting knowledge.

punchline.text: Cramming passes tests. Spacing builds expertise.

quiz.question: Why does cramming lead to rapid memory decay?
options: Massed practice creates fragile memories without proper consolidation
Cramming is always ineffective for any test
